abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings show a satisfactory
            outcome, highly likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. Lessons are addressed as
            follows. The Project design provided a framework, with clear
            principles in terms of targeting, ownership, and
            implementation arrangements, and, provided in addition the
            needed flexibility regarding emerging market opportunities,
            which could not be anticipated early on. Reflecting on the
            multiple objectives of components, which could have had a
            potential risk of conflict, its objectives however, were
            sharply defined, and priorities agreed upon. In so doing,
            while the irrigation component was designed for its
            contribution to grain outputs, and for a positive impact on
            the protection of groundwater resources, the country
            however, moved towards a grain surplus situation, and grain
            prices dropped. But the financially most attractive crops,
            needed to be supplied with groundwater, e.g., greenhouses or
            vegetables require regular irrigation year round, for which
            surface water is less suitable, thus the irrigation
            component proved successful. Investments in agro-processing
            can only be successful, if management, and ownership
            structures are equipped to commercially compete in
            today's business environment, for the project
            supported, by and large, highly successful, privately owned,
            and managed processing enterprises, but at the expense of
            state-owned enterprises, thus failing to enter into
            commercial operation. Despite foreseeing these difficulties,
            the understanding, and commitment to change ownership, and
            management came mostly too late. Further lessons reinforce
            the importance of an effective project management, namely on
            building capacity, on procurement issues, and financial
            management; and, of Bank staff continuity.
